oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mt. Olivet Cemetery: Miliken Fields family plot
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: E. Forest Ave, Jackson, Madison County, Tennessee

Color photograph of Miliken-Fields family plot. Front row contains three grave markers. Left flat marker's inscription reads "Davis T. Fields, Oct. 4, 1896, May 24, 1970" and right flat marker's inscription reads "Joe Ray Miliken, Oct. 13, 1944, Apr. 25, 1985." Central angled tombstone's facade inscription bears the family surnames "Miliken Fields." Government-issued military marker mounted to the angled tombstone reads "Jimmy Leon Miliken, SN US Navy, Vietnam, Sep. 26, 1942, Aug. 9, 1984." Middle row contains two flat grave markers, the left one's inscription reads "Ruby May Miliken, 1911, 1921." Back row contains a central tombstone inscribed with the surnames. Old domed, tabled style tombstone is located to the right of the back row's central tombstone. Tombstone to the left of the back's central tombstone is inscribed with the surname "Collins." Cracked tombstone appears in the left background.

Established in 1885, Mt. Olivet Cemetery is the largest, private African American cemetery in Jackson, and is still in use today. It was especially popular with the growing upper middle class and professional segment of the local black community from 1890 to 1930. Based on a 1995 survey of extant cemetery grave markers, the earliest marked burial is from 1885. Prominent burials include doctors, ministers, businessmen, a lawyer, veterans, and many educators. The grave markers also indicate membership in specific clubs, and fraternal and civic organizations, especially those grave markers between 1917 and 1988. The markers indicate particular importance on the graves of children, or "innocents." The cemetery is a symbol of local artisanship, and the success of Jackson's postbellum black community.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American cemeteries; Graveposts;
tombstones; inscriptions;
